fields.title: Padėkos vakaras su Nomeda
fields.body: Artėjant padėkos šventei Lietuvos Generalinis konsulatas Niujorke 2013 m. lapkričio 26 d., antradienį, 18:30 val. kviečia į Nomedos Marčėnaitės keramikos darbų parodos atidarymą ir pašnekesių vakarą su menininke prie taurės vyno.

fields.title: Padėkos dienos pietūs Niujorko Apreiškimo parapijoje
fields.body:
Gruodžio 1 d., sekmadienį, 10:00 val. Niujorko Apreiškimo parapija maloniai kviečia Jus atvykti su savo šeima, artimaisiais bei visais draugais į tradicines mūsų bendruomenės Padėkos dienos vaišes. Po lietuviškų pamaldų bus pasiūlyti šilti pietūs ir gėrimai. Galėsite gardžiai pasivaišinti, linksmai pabendrauti!

Mes linkime Jums ir Jūsų šeimoms gražios Padėkos dienos šventės.

Adresas:

259 North 5th Street
Brooklyn, New York 11211

Apreiškimo parapijos interneto svetainė: "http://www.nyapreiskimo.com":http://www.nyapreiskimo.com

fields.title: Lietuvių kilmės muzikanto Taddes Korris koncertas
fields.body:
Koncertas vyks gruodžio 13 d. nuo 20:30 val. iki 22:00 val. adresu

Manhattan School of Music
Greenfield Hall
120 Claremont Ave
New York, NY 10027

Programoje:
* Copland: Appalachian Spring
* Stravinsky: Soldier's Tale
* Schoenberg: Chamber Symphony No. 1

h2. Apie Taddes Korris

Taddes Korris is a dynamic orchestral, chamber and solo performer of the double bass.  Born into a Lithuanian family in Canada, his unique cultural roots inspire him to create and perform works not known to audiences. Seeking to create vivid programs that inspire audiences, Korris’ musical objectives seek to rekindle society’s interest in classical music in the modern world through creative and innovative means.

As chamber musician, Korris is actively involved in inter-arts collaborations embracing technology, dance, art and film.  He is driven by the idea that chamber music can be the most intimate and transformative form of music that can touch and engage people.  With a passion for history and culture, he unifies audiences through programs that combine popular music and classical music as one.  Korris’ performance programs have been seen in venues throughout the New York City area.

Taddes’ chamber music collaborations have included the works of Richard Strauss, Sergei Prokofiev, Arnold Schoenberg, Richard Danielpour, Igor Stravinsky and many others.  Most recently  Korris is involved in a string septet, coached by renowned violinist Curtis Macomber . This ensemble has numerous performances booked to play Arnold Schoenberg’s Transfigured Night and R. Strauss’ Metamorphosen, both  partly adapted by Korris from their orchestral versions to septet. In 2009 he performed Richard Danielpour’s Sweet Talk under the direction of the composer himself.

In the summer of 2009, Taddes attended the Brevard Music Festival in North Carolina under scholarship.  Here, having achieved the highest audition score of all the double basses he was invited to play in the Cardenes Chamber Orchestra, led by Andres Cardenes, renowned violinist, concertmaster of the Pittsburgh Symphony and Grammy nominated artist .  Taddes also served as principal bass for the Brevard Sinfonia’s performance of Prokofiev’s Romeo and Juliet under distinguished maestro Matthias Bamert.

In the summer of 2007, Taddes was the only Canadian to attend the Carl Flesch Academy in Baden-Baden, Germany.  Here, he studied under Janne Saksala, principal bass of the Berlin Philharmonic.  The same summer, he attended the Tibor Varga masterclass program in Sion, Switzerland to study with the world renowned bassist Duncan McTier.

In May, 2007, in cooperation with the Lithuanian Society of Edmonton and, Taddes recruited 66 young Canadian musicians to record the rare works of Lithuanian composer Mikalojus Ciurlionis.  He acted as the principal bass, personnel manager and librarian of the orchestra liaising between orchestra, conductor and recording engineers.   As a result of this project Taddes was one of the recipients of the Top 20 Under 20 Award and also awarded a mentorship with Order of Canada recipient George Zukerman through the Governor General's office.

Taddes continues his ongoing passion of Lithuanian music by promoting it and furthering its place in the North American repertoire.  He has arranged numerous works for double bass and cello and is in the process of preparing a variety of performances in the New York area of both Lithuanian music and music suppressed by the Soviet and Nazi regimes.  His goal is to spearhead more recording projects and performances of Lithuanian music and to promote the work of less known composers.

Taddes began his studies of the double bass at 16 with Jan Urke, Principal Bass of the Edmonton Symphony Orchestra in Canada.  He then studied at McGill University from 2007-2008 pursuing studies in Russian and Soviet history as well as music.  In May 2008, Taddes was offered a special audition at the Manhattan School of Music in New York where he is to begin his Master's degree with Timothy Cobb.   His previous teachers include Jeremy McCoy and David Grossman.  He has performed in masterclasses for Ira Gold, Max Dimoff, Duncan McTier, Rinat Ibragimov, Janne Saksala, Mark Morton and Clive Greensmith.  Taddes plays a circa. 1790 Viennese bass with a bow by Vincenzo DeLuccia.

Muzikanto interneto svetainė: "http://www.taddeskorris.com/":http://www.taddeskorris.com/

fields.title: Džiazo vokalistė Simona Smirnova
fields.body:
Gruodžio 12, 2013 ketvirtadienį džiazo vokalistė Simona Smirnova su Berklee muzikos koledžo dėstytojais ir kitais studentais pasirodys Niujorke.

Koncertas vyks Cotton Club of New York, Harleme. Koncertas prasidės 9.30pm. Rezervaciją pageidautina padaryti iš anksto, kadangi dažniausiai klubas būna perpildytas.

fields.title: Kūčios Niujorke
fields.body:
Tuojau po 10:00 val. lietuviškų šv. Mišių Apreiškimo bažnyčioje, prašome atvykti 11:00 val. į Mt. Carmel bažnyčios salę adresu:

Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church
275 N 8th St
Brooklyn, NY 11211

Programoje: NY Maironio mokyklos mokiniai pristato LIETUVIŠKĄ SKAITYKLĘ su SKAIDRĖMIS, deklamuodami lietuvių autorių eilėraščius apie žiemą.

Visų laukia tradiciniai Kūčių valgiai, Kalėdinės giesmės, Kalėdų Senelis.

Įėjimo auka: 
* Suaugusiems perkant iš anksto - $15.00
* Suaugusiems prie durų šventės metu - $20.00 
* Vaikams nuo 3 - 16 metų - $5.00
* Vaikams iki 3 metų - nemokamai

Rengėjai:
* Niujorko Maironio lituanistinė mokykla
* Apreiškimo parapija
* LSS skautai Niujorke

Malonėkite bilietus įsigyti iš anksto pas:

fields.title: Kalėdinė eglutė ir tradicinės Kūčios Ročesteryje
fields.body:

fields.title: Rasos Pranckūnaitės darbai Brooklyn Museum of Art
fields.body:
Rasa Pranckūnaitė viena iš menininkų, eksponuojančių savo darbus šioje mugėje. Tuo pačiu trurėsite galimybę pamatyti prancūzų dizainerio J. P. Gaultier "The fashion world" parodą. Taip pat labai idomią tapytojos Wangeshi Mutu parodą.

Informacija telefonais:
* (845) 355-2400
* (718) 638-5000

Muziejaus įėjimo kainos yra "suggested donation".

Rasos Pranckūnaitės tinklapis "www.rasaart.com":http://www.rasaart.com
Muziejaus tinklapis: "www.brooklynmuseum.org":http://www.brooklynmuseum.org


First Annual American Fine Craft Show at

Brooklyn Museum of Art
200 Eastern Parkway
Brooklyn, NY 11238

Saturday, December 14 - 15, 2013 at 11 a.m. – 6:00 p.m. at the Beaux-Arts Court, 3rd Floor

Come do your holiday shopping at the first annual American Fine Craft Show Brooklyn! Craft aficionados can browse the collections of 90 jury-selected artists and artisans. Works will include ceramics, decorative and wearable fiber, furniture, glass, jewelry, leather, sculpture, and fine art, with many of the nation’s master craftspeople showing in New York for the first time. 

The craft show entrance fee includes Museum admission. Tickets are $12 for adults, $11 for seniors, $6 for students with valid ID, and free for children under 10.

fields.title: Šiuolaikinė lietuviška opera "Have a Good Day!"
fields.body:
Seansai:
* Sausio 15 -18 dienomis -8:30PM
* Sausio 19 d. - 4:00PM

Personalas:
* Kompozitorė - Lina Lapelytė
* Libreto autorė - Vaiva Grainytė
* Režisierė - Rugilė Barzdžiukaitė
* Prodiuserė - Ana Ablamonova

"http://prototypefestival.org/shows/listing/":http://prototypefestival.org/shows/listing/

Have a Good Day! is an ode about capitalism that illustrates the inevitability of consumption. In the opera by composer Lina Lapelytė and librettist Vaiva Grainytė, directed by Rugilė Barzdžiukaitė, the anonymous cashier one meets every day takes on the nuances of an individual character. Performers reject a classical vocalizing and instead the cashiers’ arias sound more like repetitive, trite melodies,reminiscent of the endless, monotonous movement of goods along a conveyor. The minimalistic score is composed of various sounds from an environment and reflects acoustic diversity of a shopping centre.The plot of this opera is set around the inner lives of cashiers in a shopping centre and looks at everything that lies behind the mechanical ‘Good afternoon. Thank you. Have a good day!’, followed by a smile. The faceless, robot-like shop workers to be found in everyday life are transformed into striking opera characters; their secret thoughts and biographies are revealed to the audience and turned into short, personal dramas. The characters of the various saleswomen represent the social landscape of Lithuania and reflect the topics of the day, such as emigration, unemployment and a patriarchate-dominant mentality, or serve as stylistic figures created for musical and textual variation.Inner monologues reflect each cashier’s personal characteristics, education, the way they speak and their personal problems. The libretto of the opera combines documentary and poetic layers. The next itself is a revealing mosaic of spoken language, poetry and social issues. To avoid any moral or condemnatory suggestion, a critical attitude towards capitalism is expressed through humor, paradox, irony and poetry. The mosaic of different destinies is transformed into one ode suggesting the pleasure of consumption. The audience is doing more than just snooping on the inner worlds of the cashiers, they are also acknowledging that they too are part of the unavoidable circle of earning and spending.The atmosphere of a supermarket is established before the audience even find their way into the hall: on the door, their tickets are checked by security guards – a very familiar presence in shopping malls – one of whom will play thepiano later on. A glinting and buzzing installation of daylight lamps connects the audience space with the ten cashiers on stage. The physical qualities of the performers are precisely tuned to the musical and textual score, each face tells a separate story. The lighting design has two layers: the first aims at creating a realistic, aesthetically cold atmosphere, whilst the second has a theatrical effect, highlighting each cashier when she sings. Goods – the obligatory decoration of a shopping center –exist only in acoustic and verbal form: monotonous melodies and an abundance of groceries attack the viewers’ ears and imagination. The only actual props are transparent lists of bar-codes that are scanned by the scanners, beeping and blinkingtheir red lights throughout the entire performance. All the cashiers in the opera are imprisoned in their workplace, only occasionally are they able to leave it for a short period.
 
Lina Lapelytė is a Lithuanian artist, composer and performer currently exploring the phenomenon of song. Using song as an object, Lina examines the issues of displacement, otherness and beauty. Lapelytė has been exhibiting and performing at the David Roberts Arts Foundation, ICA (London), BBC Proms, Tate Modern, CAC (Vilnius), CCA (Glasgow), Ikon (Birmingham), Skopje Biennale and the Holland Festival.

Vaiva Grainytė is a Lithuanian writer, poet, essayist and editor of art news website www.kamane.lt. Studied theatre history and critics at the Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theatre (Vilnius). Using her texts as media, she collaborateswith various artists. Her debut book “Beijing Diaries” was nominated for the “Book of the Year 2012”. In 2012 the opera “Have a Good Day!” libretto was selected by Women Playwrights International Conference jury and includedinto the readings programme (Sweden, Stockholm).

Rugilė Barzdžiukaitė completed documentary film, theatre directing and cinematography studies. She applies interdisciplinary experience in film and theatre works, avoiding direct synthesis of expressions, meanwhile exploring the tensionbetween documentary and fiction, performing and being, filming and seeing. Rugilė’s audiovisual works in Ireland, Russia, and South Africa were granted prizes and scholarships.

Ana Ablamonova is a Lithuanian performing arts producer with 9 years experience acquired mostly in the field of music theatre. Founder and director of Contemporary opera festival NOA (New Opera Action) and movement of contemporary music theatreand interdisciplinary art OPEROMANIJA. Graduated with Master’s degree in Music Management from the Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theatre (2009). Also holds a Master’s degree in Choir Conducting from the Saint Petersburg State Universityof Culture and Arts (2007).  Winner of the EU program for young art managers “Gulliver Connect”."  Her productions are appreciated on national and international levels: Best Stage Work of the Year (cycle of operas at the 1st Contemporary opera festival NOA, 2008),Lithuanian Golden Stage Cross (best debut of the year – monodrama-opera “Izadora”, 2009), Theatre NOW (award of Tbilisi International Theatre Festival for the multimedia opera “ID”, 2011), Globe-Teana Theatre Observation Award (Music Theatre NOWcompetition and for the opera “Have a Good Day!”, 2013).2010–2013 – Member of the Opera Europa Young Delegates Think Tank.Since 2012 Ana has served as  Head of the Art Centre at the Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theatre.

The key sound throughout the opera is the monotonous beeping that happens every time an item is scanned. It might get louder or quieter, but it is always there. The songs that accompany the beeping are as monotonous as the process of shopping and selling. Instead of becoming the main focus of the opera, the music underlines the thoughts of the cashiers – it enables us to hear their voice.

fields.body:
